solution.text:
volume of metallic toy = Volume of the hemisphere + volume of the cone
Now volume of the hemisphere\(=\frac 23 [\pi \times r^3]\) radius of the cone=\(_{j}_\)
\(\Rightarrow \frac 23 \times \frac {22}7 \times _{j}_^3=_{{trunc(2*pi_val*j*j*j/3,2)}}_\)
volume of the cone on top the hemisphere\(=[ \frac 13 \times \pi \times r^2 \times height]\)
height of the cone = height of the toy - height of the hemisphere= _{k}_
volume of the cone\(=[ \frac 13 \times \frac {22}7 \times _{j}_^2 \times _{k}_]= _{{trunc(pi_val*j*j*k/3,2)}}_\)
Now the volume of the toy\(=_{{trunc(pi_val*j*j*k/3,2)}}_ + _{{trunc(2*pi_val*j*j*j/3,2)}}_\)
\(\Rightarrow _{{trunc(pi_val*j*j*k/3+2*pi_val*j*j*j/3,2)}}_cm^3\)
mass of the toy = mass of 1 \(cm^3\) of metal \(\times \) volume of the toy
\(\Rightarrow _{l}_ \times _{{trunc(pi_val*j*j*k/3+2*pi_val*j*j*j/3,2)}}_ = _{{trunc(l*(pi_val*j*j*k/3+2*pi_val*j*j*j/3),2)}}_g \)

content.text:
A metallic toy is in the shape of a hemisphere surmounted by a right circular cone
If H is _{{j+k}}_cm and radius of the cone is _{j}_ cm then find the mass of the toy,
given that 1\(cm^3\) of the metal has approximately _{l}_g mass.
